Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: Microfluidic Platform for Accurate Sampling of Biological Signaling Events
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Virginia Tech to develop a microfluidic device that will enable real-time monitoring of fast cellular events, to increase the fidelity of in vitro generated phosphor-proteomic data necessary for the elucidation of biological signaling pathways. Reversible protein phosphorylation in response to external stimuli represents a key regulatory mechanism that triggers essential cellular signaling events. Aberrant phosphorylation of Ser, Thr and Tyr is often involved in diseases such as cancer, inflammation, diabetes and metabolic disorders. The time-scale of signaling phosphorylation events is very short, ranging from sec to min. Therefore, if the sampling strategy and frequency of the stimulated cells is not adequate, accurate time-dependent concentration profiles of phosphorylated proteins, as well as global profiling of signaling pathways, cannot be performed. The microfluidic device that will be developed in this research will integrate a series of functional elements that will enable the acquisition of accurate time-dependent protein phosphorylation profiles and unambiguous mass spectrometry detection and localization of phosphorylation sites. Phospho-signaling events will be sampled with less than 1 sec delay from occurrence, from phosphor-proteins present in concentrations as low as ~1 fmol. Large-scale integration of functional elements on the chip will lead to 10-100 fold reduction in sample consumption and costs. The microfluidic device will be used to explore the signaling pathways that control cell cycle progression and cellular innate immune responses to Newcastle disease virus in cancer cells. In a broader context, the microfluidic platform will enable the collection of biological data that could help elucidate the mechanisms of aberrant cell behavior, the properties of dysfunctional signaling cascades and of cross-talk between signaling networks, and the development of effective drug treatments for various diseased cell states. On the computational level, it will help discover and validate novel theoretical principles that describe the rate and characteristics of the signal propagation process. On the engineering level, it will facilitate the development of high-performance instrumentation and biomedical infrastructure.

This award will enable students and researchers to become visionary scientists that can further advance the forefront of biological research. The education/outreach program will include on-line and on-site interdisciplinary student training in chemistry, biology and engineering concepts, the development of new laboratory modules for graduate and undergraduate students at VT, summer internships to high-school students and under-represented undergraduate minorities, and enhancement of infrastructure for research and education. A dissemination plan will be put in place to engage faculty and scientists with diverse background in collaborations that can benefit from the newly developed technology. The knowledge generated through this research will be disseminated through publications in scientific journals, conference presentations and workshops, and on-line and news-room articles that raise the scientific literacy of the public. Industrial partners will be identified to promote the commercialization of the device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

The response of cells to physical or chemical stimuli is complex, unfolding on time-scales from seconds to days, with or without de novo protein synthesis, and involving signaling processes that are transient or sustained. By combining the technology of microfluidics, that supports fast and accurate execution of a variety of cell handling operations, with that of mass spectrometry (MS), that enables the detection and quantitation of low-abundance target peptides and their phosphorylated states, our goal was to develop a platform that will enable the capture of changes in protein expression and phosphorylation levels that are indicative of cellular responses to a perturbation, such as treatment with mitogens. Specifically, we have pursued the following tasks: (a) We investigated the signaling pathways that are activated upon stimulation of a model HER2+ breast cancer cell line (SKBR3), determined the proteins that become phosphorylated and contribute to signal transduction, and selected a few representative proteins and peptide for the development and demonstration of microfluidic devices; (b) We developed microreactors for enzymatic digestion of proteins, and enrichment of phosphopeptides and separations, that enabled direct interfacing to MS detection; (c) We developed microfluidic devices that enabled cell capture, stimulation, lysis and sample collection for MS analysis; (d) We developed protocols for fast processing of cellular extracts, enzymatic treatment of proteins, enrichment, and targeted detection and quantitation of phosphorylated peptides; and (e) We assessed the applicability of our platform in the context of studying time-sensitive cellular responses.

The microfluidic devices that were developed enabled the detection of hundreds of proteins (or thousands with advanced MS instrumentation) representative of all major cellular compartments and biological processes, including signal transduction pathways such as p38 MAPK, ERK, PI3K that involve rapid and/or transient protein phosphorylation processes. Protein phosphorylation could be detected at ~10 nM level. We expect to be able to monitor cellular changes that are induced as soon as ~1-2 min after stimulation, and that occur with a transient manifestation of no less than ~5 min. The value of this microfluidic approach arises from the superior analytical capabilities for fast and sensitive handling of minute amounts of proteomic samples, in particular: the integrated layout minimizes sample losses and provides at least a 10-fold increase in throughput in comparison to conventional cell processing approaches; the multi-functional format enables specific tasks to be accomplished within 5-15 min and total sample processing within ~30-60 min instead of hours/days; reagent consumption is reduced ~100-fold; the simple, versatile and small footprint (1”x 2”) enables incorporation into more complex workflows; and, MS detection provides the sensitivity, specificity and resolving power for unambiguous detection of trace level components.

The microfluidic platforms that resulted from this work lay the groundwork for future technology development for collecting and exploring biological data that could help elucidate the mechanisms of aberrant cell behavior and the properties of dysfunctional signaling networks. The bioanalytical approaches for sample processing will support the development of fast, high-throughput workflows aimed at assessing changes in protein expression or in their PTMs. Altogether, our platform will support the advance of novel micro-analytical systems and phosphoprotein detection strategies with applicability in any field of biological, biomedical, biochemical and pharmaceutical sciences, including lab-on-a-chip diagnostics, precision medicine applications, and pharmacokinetic-pharmacodynamic studies.

The research performed during the duration of the project led to ten (10) research articles, two book chapters (2), three (3) education/outreach articles, three (3) datasets, two (2) patent disclosures, twenty one (21) presentations at international and national conferences and symposia (21), and twenty six (26) presentations at local conferences and events.

Broader impact

An important aspect of the education/outreach program of this proposal included interdisciplinary training of students through coursework and experimental research. A total of 22 students (6 graduate, 3 graduate rotation, 10 undergraduate and 3 high-school) were trained directly on various experimental and theoretical aspects of mass spectrometry, proteomics, microfluidics and bioinformatics for processing proteomics data. Findings of this research were included in graduate coursework, and undergraduate courses aimed at interdisciplinary training in the College of Science, such as the newly developed Systems Biology and Integrated Science Curriculum. Both experimental and theoretical teaching efforts reached students with diverse background in biology, chemistry, engineering, nanoscience and neuroscience. Summer training activities were offered to under-represented minorities and high-schools students. The results of the project were disseminated through publications, multiple national and international conferences and symposia, news-room articles, local presentations, undergraduate forums, and science fair events.
